text: how is this visit being viewed in Russia
what's the rhetoric at the moment well I
think the official rhetoric here is that
the u.s. administration is trying to
mend fences with Russia that it finally
decided to take up a more sensible
course and instead of isolating Russia
has sent the Secretary of State to Sochi
to meet with top ranking Russian
officials to discuss some of the urgent
business so here it is cast as a sign of
a change in the u.s. policy of avoiding
any negotiation with Russia and trying
to at least make sure the United States
and Russia are on the same page on a
number of pressing international issues
Mikell relations have widely been called
the chilliest in decades and the worst
they've been in about 30 years how is it
being spun in the US well thank you I
think in the u.s. that's being
downplayed a bit as just a routine
regular visit of course we know it's not
John Kerry after this is going on to
Turkey to Istanbul so she's not on the
way to Istanbul and frankly John Kerry
has been meeting with a secretary Lavrov
pretty much everywhere outside of Russia
in the past two years quite frequently
so the channels of communication I feel
between the United States and Russia
have been open these past two years but
the problem is that secretary Lavrov
does not really represent
decision-making in Russia or
decision-making ultimately lies with
Vladimir Putin and I think the United
States had sought to have a meeting with
lemare Putin my impression is the fact
that this meeting alone is taking place
suggest that some progress behind the

both sides to believe that there could

necessarily a headline but yeah what do

what issues could they actually make

Syria
definitely not Ukraine we can imagine
what about the idea of sanctions could

least report on such disc
Russians but of course I think it is now
the United States that wants to make
sure that Russia is on the same page
with it and other negotiators on the
Iran nuclear dossier and also I think
the Syria conflict might be an important
hot spot now to deal with in order to
show the Arab allies of the United
States and Israel that Iran can actually
be a constructive player in in terms of
security in the Middle East if all those
powers are to reach an agreement on
lifting of the sanctions against Iran so
here I think Russia plays an
instrumental role in negotiating a deal
with President Bashar Assad of Syria so
I wouldn't be surprised if secretary
Kerry has this kind of issue high on his
agenda of negotiations with Putin Michel
given though America's pivot towards
Asia their interest in China how do they
actually view the relationship with
Russia in terms of how meaningful it
should be how important it is well I
think that this relationship has always
been viewed in the United States a
little bit as more of a second order
perhaps third order relationship and
that has always very frustrated and
bothered Russia Russia is always quite
fixated on the United States whereas the
United States is rather focused on the
Middle East and secondary in the Asia
Pacific region on China and I think if
you looked in the past couple of years
you'll see a lot of actions to Russia's
taking that seem quite provocative but
fundamentally their intent is to put
Russia on America's radar and in some
respects perhaps is a sign that it has
worked because where Russia's always
sought is for the United States to
generally come and negotiate with it and
look for potential compromise in the
major areas of intractable disagreement
one being Ukraine the second one being
Syria in the United States had always
had very little motivation to do that
because it believes that Russia is
fundamentally a regional power in
structural decline so why should
American negotiate with Russia today
when Marshalls always going to be weaker
tomorrow has always been disinclined to
